dt: {bc}a wife or mother that is a source of offspring

et: borrowed from New Latin, going back to Latin
dt: {bc}a protuberant and often hollow anatomical structure: such as
{bc}the undersurface of the abdomen of an arthropod
{bc}the swollen basal portion of an archegonium in which an egg develops

et: borrowed from Anglo-French {it}ventre{/it} "belly, womb, mother," going back to Latin {it}ventr-, venter{/it} "belly, womb, bulge"; perhaps, if going back to {it}*wet-ri-{/it} or {it}*wed-ri-{/it} (with nasal of uncertain origin), akin to Latin {it}uterus{/it} "womb," Sanskrit {it}udara-{/it} {ma}{mat|uterus|}{/ma}
shortdef: a wife or mother that is a source of offspring
a protuberant and often hollow anatomical structure: such as
the undersurface of the abdomen of an arthropod
